org.apache.hadoop.fs.swift.snative

Class SwiftNativeFileSystemStore

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.hadoop.fs.swift.snative.SwiftNativeFileSystemStore

  • public class SwiftNativeFileSystemStore
extends Object
    File system store implementation. Makes REST requests, parses data from responses

      • rename

        public void rename(org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path src,
                   org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path dst)
            throws FileNotFoundException,
                   SwiftOperationFailedException,
                   IOException
        Rename through copy-and-delete. this is a consequence of the Swift filesystem using the path as the hash into the Distributed Hash Table, "the ring" of filenames.

        Because of the nature of the operation, it is not atomic.

        Parameters:
        src - source file/dir
        dst - destination
        Throws:
        IOException - IO failure
        SwiftOperationFailedException - if the rename failed
        FileNotFoundException - if the source directory is missing, or the parent directory of the destination

      • copy

        public void copy(org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path srcKey,
                 org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path dstKey)
          throws IOException
        Throws:
        IOException

        Take a Hadoop path and return one which uses the URI prefix and authority of this FS. It doesn't make a relative path absolute
        Parameters:
        path - path in
        Returns:
        path with a URI bound to this FS
        Throws:
        SwiftException - URI cannot be created.

      • delete

        public boolean delete(org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path absolutePath,
                      boolean recursive)
               throws IOException
        Delete the entire tree. This is an internal one with slightly different behavior: if an entry is missing, a FileNotFoundException is raised. This lets the caller distinguish a file not found with other reasons for failure, so handles race conditions in recursive directory deletes better.

        The problem being addressed is: caller A requests a recursive directory of directory /dir ; caller B requests a delete of a file /dir/file, between caller A enumerating the files contents, and requesting a delete of /dir/file. We want to recognise the special case "directed file is no longer there" and not convert that into a failure

        Parameters:
        absolutePath - the path to delete.
        recursive - if path is a directory and set to true, the directory is deleted else throws an exception if the directory is not empty case of a file the recursive can be set to either true or false.
        Returns:
        true if the object was deleted
        Throws:
        IOException - IO problems
        FileNotFoundException - if a file/dir being deleted is not there - this includes entries below the specified path, (if the path is a dir and recursive is true)
